issue.title: \newcommand redefines TeX commands (such as \begin, \mathbf, ...)
issue.body:
### Issue Summary

When defining a new command (using `\newcommand` or `\def`) on a line **before** a command such as `\begin{...}`; in the process of typing that, it will redefine `\begin` to whatever is in the braces, essentially breaking any environments defined with `\begin`.
This issue is not specific to `\begin`, though.

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Starting point
```
$$
\begin{aligned}
a = 3
\end{aligned}
$$
```
2. Type `\newcommand` on the first line to get
```
$$
\newcommand

\begin{aligned}
a = 3
\end{aligned}
$$
```

At this point, `\begin` is redefined to `aligned`, even though `\begin` is already a defined command. Also, the purpose was to define another command entirely, but in the process of writing it, something else got redefined too.
Ideally, one would be able to define a **new** command at the top without having to worry that stuff could break by accident while typing out the command.

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3.2
* Client OS: Linux 5.19.9-arch1-1
* Browser: Vivaldi 5.4.2753.51 (Stable channel) stable (64-bit) 

I am using the following MathJax configuration:
Live demo on [https://www.mathjax.org/#demo](https://www.mathjax.org/#demo)

comment.body:
What you suggest would certainly work, but note that it is a solution based on the *editor* being used, not on MathJax itself.  The demo page is really just a simple textarea element that copies its content to the display area and calls MathJax to typeset it after each keypress.  It is not a fancy editor, and is only meant as a simple playground, not a sophisticated text editor.  While we could add more features to it, like the braces you are suggesting, that would only fix the issue on *our* page, not for any other page that allows you to enter LaTeX notation (e.g., the StackExchange sites).

So this is not an issue that is solved within MathJax itself, but within the framework that is *using* MathJax.  I will leave this open as a feature request for the demo page, but it is not likely to see any action in the near future.

issue.title: How to reset MathJax instance welly both V2 and V3
issue.body:
### Issue Summary

I need to reset MathJax instance in order to re-render the page with same instance, however I tried lot ways, it always ends up some issues.

**For version 2**, I use this workaround to do the reset job:

```html
<script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@2/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS_CHTML"></script>
```

```js
MathJax.Hub.Queue(
  ['PreProcess', MathJax.Hub],
  ['resetEquationNumbers', MathJax.InputJax.TeX],
  ['PreProcess', MathJax.Hub],
  ['Reprocess', MathJax.Hub]
);

```
It works fine for re-rendering page, but sometimes I will get:
```
Uncaught Error: Can't make callback from given data
    USING http://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@2/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS_CHTML:19
    Push http://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@2/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS_CHTML:19
    Queue http://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@2/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS_CHTML:19
```
Related to [issue#2935](https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax/issues/2935)

**For version 3**, already tried following reset functions:
```js
MathJax.startup.document.state();
MathJax.texReset();
MathJax.typesetClear()
```

But it will end up to:

```
Label 'eq:m1' multiply defined
```

For the temporary workaround, I can re-render labels without getting any error by:

```html
<script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

```js
MathJax.startup.output.clearCache();
MathJax.startup.getComponents();
```
If this will be ok?

But if I change to use svg on **Chrome 105**(without change anything else):
```html
<script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-svg.js"></script>
```
Will always get:
```
tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:39500 Error: MathJax retry
    at e.retryAfter (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:41256:25)
    at L (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:20310:110)
    at c (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:16727:31)
    at e.parse (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:14673:31)
    at t.parse (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:12635:50)
    at t.parse (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:15329:63)
    at t.controlSequence (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:13186:23)
    at t.parse (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:14507:39)
    at t.parse (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:12635:50)
    at t.parse (tex-mml-svg.js:formatted:15329:63)
```

### Steps to Reproduce:

- Clone [docsify-latex](https://github.com/scruel/docsify-latex/), enter into repo folder
- Modify `docs/index.md` with following text:
```latex
When $a \ne 0$, there are two solutions to $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$ and they are $\ref{eq:m1}$

$$
x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}.\tag{M1}\label{eq:m1}
$$

This equation $\eqref{eq:m1}$ is very important.

```
- Click to switch to `/#/example` page, then switch back to `/#/`
- Start the server to review via:

```shell
cd docs && python -m SimpleHTTPServer 3000
```
or

```shell
npm i docsify-cli -g
docsify serve docs
```
- You can see the result

For version 2:

- Replace MathJax v3 script to v2, do same steps as v3.

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 2,7.9, 3.2.2
* Client OS: Windows 10
* Browser: Firefox

### Supporting information:

Check this commit:
https://github.com/scruel/docsify-latex/commit/136fe8c5950543107644281fdc4577c47aa7cd96#diff-ee52eacc98a34424ac3b8149882469d47619cc1e6c05e00d86bbba97c11d714d

comment.body:
I am not able to reproduce the errors you are seeing in either version 2 or version 3.  The page renders fine after switching to the example and back.

The `MathJax.texReset()` command should reset the labels, but perhaps there is a timing issue with when you are calling this, or that your typesetting code is being called more than once.  I don't know how docsify works, and don' have the time to work that out myself.

The issue you are having with the callbacks in v2 is probably the one I mentioned in one of your other issues where the v2 configuration hasn't been loaded when your code tries to use `MathJax.InputJax.TeX`.

I'm not sure why you are doing the preprocessing twice.  In fact, I'm not sure why you don't just to a single

``` js
MathJax.Hub.Queue(['Typeset', MathJax.Hub]);
```
 
call.

So I'm not sure what to tell you, here, as I can't reproduce the issue you seem to be having.

issue.title: How to add event listeners to rendered chtml?

comment.body:
There is no mechanism currently for doing what you request.  As you point out, event listeners are not included in the contents of `outerHTML`, and so are lost if you serialize MathJax's DOM elements in this way (as would be the case for listeners from *any* piece of DOM you serialize via `outerHTML`).  The event listeners used by MathJax include references to various internal structures of the parsed TeX expression via closures, and those can not be easily recreated after `innerHTML` has been used, as those structures will no longer exist.

The only way I can see doing this would be to collect the listeners into a separate structure as they are being created, and mark the elements on which they are to be attached, and store the listeners keys to those markers.  Then when the serialized HTML is inserted into the document, run through the list of listeners and add them into the appropriate items using the markers to identify them.  While possible, that would require significant changes internally in MathJax that would not be easy to do via a run-time patch to MathJax.  Plus you would still need to manage the listener structure yourself.  So I'm not sure it gains you very much.

issue.title: `mjx-container` box width should be wider than actual content width
issue.body:
### Issue Summary
I am trying to add scroll bar for overflowed equations, and tried [the workaround from stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/65321568/mathjax-3-inline-math-and-overflow-x), then I updated my plugin on this [commit](https://github.com/scruel/docsify-latex/commit/a7ae50a756a816f840ecd8234561aaf2107be53d) and tested it with different browsers, for Safari, I will always get an unexpected scroll bar for the equation `\LaTex`:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16933298/192150024-1001fe8c-7086-4098-be27-5c5553e50d3c.png)

After investigated a little while, I found that Chrome and Safari will render content to a little wider `mjx-math` box, compare to Firefox and Edge.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16933298/192153660-f1397fea-5508-4d36-adef-ee9ec227ee88.png)
If I remove the `width` style for `mjx-math`, scroll bar will be disappeared, and will get the inner content width as following:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16933298/192150008-0ec19a5d-b677-48fb-90b4-85c981712f0a.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16933298/192149990-8cdb6622-c3b2-470e-981e-eb15342db43c.png)

### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Safari or Chrome (set screen size to 320x285)
2. Create a simple HTML:
```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<body>
  <script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
</body>
</html>
```
3. Type following in console, then execute:
```js
var outer = document.createElement('p');
document.body.append(outer);
var ele = document.createElement('div');
ele.style = 'max-width: 100%;display: inline-grid;overflow-x: auto;overflow-y:hidden;'
ele.innerHTML="\\(\\LaTeX\\)";
outer.append('typesetting ');
outer.append(ele);
MathJax.typesetPromise([ele])
```

Then:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16933298/192151119-747fcb07-581c-4220-853f-3f1ede58c2b1.png)

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3.2.2
* Client OS: Windows 10
* Browser: 105.0.5195.127

I am using the following MathJax configuration:
DEFAULT CONFIGURATION

issue.title: `MathJax.InputJax.TeX` sometimes will not be defined
issue.body:
### Issue Summary
Might be related to https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax/pull/1464, but this issue caused by `MathJax.InputJax.TeX` sometimes will not be defined.

### Steps to Reproduce:
```html
<script src="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@2/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS_CHTML"></script>
<script>MathJax.InputJax.TeX.resetEquationNumbers</script>
```

Refresh page repeatedly until error occur

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 2.7.9
* Client OS: Windows 10
* Browser: Firefox 105

I am using the following MathJax configuration:
DEFAULT CONFIGURATION

comment.body:
In MathJax v2, the `MathJax.js`, it is the configuration file that defines and instantiates the input jax that you are using.  So `MathJax.InputJax.TeX` is not defined in `MathJax.js` itself, but in the `TeX-AMS_CHTML` configuration file.  The configuration file is loaded asynchronously, so although the browser waits for `MathJax.js` to be loaded before processing your following `<script>` tag, it does not wait for the configuration to load before that is executed.  So it is entirely possible for your following script to run before MathJax's configuration is loaded and processed.  That means `MathJax.InputJax.TeX` may not be available when that command runs.  If the configuration file is in your browser cash, it may be processed first, but if not, your second script is very likely to run before the configuration is even downloaded, and you will get the undefined object error.

That is why you need to synchronize your actions with MathJax's loading operations.  This is done via a `<script type="text/x-mathjax-config">` script that appears **before** the script that loads `MathJax.js` itself.  This script will be executed during MathJax's startup process, after the configuration file is loaded, so that you can be sure that all the components are in place when your script runs.  See the [v2 startup documentation](https://docs.mathjax.org/en/v2.7-latest/advanced/startup.html) for details of the startup process, especially item 2 in the actions pushed on the queue.  See also the [configuration](https://docs.mathjax.org/en/v2.7-latest/configuration.html#using-in-line-configuration-options) documentation for more on the configuration scripts; though it mostly only talks about calling `MathJax.Hub.Config()` in that block, you can call any MathJax functions at that point.

If the code you need to call can not be put into such a script, then perhaps you can use that script to set a flag that lets you know when MathJax is loaded and ready, and have your other code check that flag.  Or set up a promise before loading mathjax and have the script resolve the promise; your other code can queue its actions using the promise so that when MathJax is ready (and calls yours mathjax-config script, which resolves the promise), they will run.

issue.title: Multiple asynchronous typesetting calls simultaneously issue
issue.body:
### Issue Summary
Perform multiple asynchronous typesetting calls simultaneously will cause chemical equations can't render correctly, or more even, an error `You can't use 'macro parameter character #' in math mode` will occur.

### Steps to Reproduce:
Type and execute in console:
```
var ele = document.createElement("div");
ele.innerHTML='$$\\ce{\\color{#F65353}{H2O}}$$';
document.body.append(ele);
MathJax.typesetPromise([ele]);

var ele = document.createElement("div");
ele.innerHTML='$$x$$';
document.body.append(ele);
MathJax.typesetPromise([ele]);
```

If you perform two typeset actions synchronously, all will be just fine.

Any other information you want to share that is relevant to the issue
being reported. Especially, why do you consider this to be a bug? What
do you expect to happen instead?

I'm not sure if it's a bug, though documentation only mention that not recommend performing multiple asynchronous typesetting calls simultaneously, rather than we can't.

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3.2.2
* Client OS: Window 10
* Browser: Firefox 105

I am using the following MathJax configuration:

DEFAULT

and loading MathJax via

``` html
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

comment.body:
That is correct, MathJax can only process one typeset call at a time, so you need to chain your `typesetPromise()` calls.

See the [documentation](https://docs.mathjax.org/en/latest/web/typeset.html#handling-asynchronous-typesetting) for some possible approaches, though it looks like you have already addressed it with `await` in your own code.

issue.title: \newcommand redefines TeX commands (such as \begin, \mathbf, ...)
issue.body:
### Issue Summary

When defining a new command (using `\newcommand` or `\def`) on a line **before** a command such as `\begin{...}`; in the process of typing that, it will redefine `\begin` to whatever is in the braces, essentially breaking any environments defined with `\begin`.
This issue is not specific to `\begin`, though.

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Starting point
```
$$
\begin{aligned}
a = 3
\end{aligned}
$$
```
2. Type `\newcommand` on the first line to get
```
$$
\newcommand

\begin{aligned}
a = 3
\end{aligned}
$$
```

At this point, `\begin` is redefined to `aligned`, even though `\begin` is already a defined command. Also, the purpose was to define another command entirely, but in the process of writing it, something else got redefined too.
Ideally, one would be able to define a **new** command at the top without having to worry that stuff could break by accident while typing out the command.

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3.2
* Client OS: Linux 5.19.9-arch1-1
* Browser: Vivaldi 5.4.2753.51 (Stable channel) stable (64-bit) 

I am using the following MathJax configuration:
Live demo on [https://www.mathjax.org/#demo](https://www.mathjax.org/#demo)

comment.body:
I'm not sure what you are asking to be done.  In LaTeX, there are two separate commands, `
ewcommand` and `enewcommand`, where the first will produce an error if you try to redefine an existing command, while the second produces an error if you use it for a command that *doesn't* already exist.  It is true that in MathJax, neither of those checks is performed (and they are both essentially the same).  

Are you asking to have the same error conditions checked as in LaTeX?  That will make the `
ewcommand` case work for you, but will still be problematic for if you re trying to type a `enewcommand` before other macros.  I do not see a way around that.  Do you have a suggestion on how it should be handled?  I think it is something you will just have to be aware of when you type in a setting where what you type is being reprocessed as you type.  One could, for example, put the `
ewcommand` in separate math delimiters to avoid the issue, or enclose it in braces until you are done typing.

issue.title: mathtools \overbracket doesn't respect \color in SVG output
issue.body: The math tools package's `\overbracket` doesn't properly handle the color set by `\color` in SVG output (but is OK in CHTML output).  E.g., `\color{red}{\overbraket{a}^{b}}` colors the `a` and `b`, but not the bracket itself.

issue.title: [SVG] (option to) remove xlink prefixes from svg output
issue.body:
[SVG2 deprecated xlink](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/linking.html#XLinkRefAttrs), [browser support for "plain" href](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/href#browser_compatibility) has been complete for a while (and in fact works on IE11 just as fine), validators also don't complain anymore.

At least having an option would be nice.

comment.body: OK, that is a good idea.

issue.title: New default font

milestone.title: v4.0
milestone.description: Items for the next release (may be 4.0 rather than 3.3).

issue.body:
This PR changes the default font from the old MathJax TeX font to the new MathJax-Modern version of Latin-Modern.  This is stored in a separate npm pages (like the other new fonts), and so the `mathjax-modern-font` package has been added as a dependency.  So you need to do `npm install` to make this work.  Because that package refers to `mathjax-full` to get access to the MathJax objects, you also need to do

``` sh
npm link
npm link mathjax-full
```

so that webpack can find the proper references when it builds the components that include the fonts.  This needs to be done *after* the `npm install`, as that command will remove the link and you'll have to do the second command again.

This looks like a lot of files, but there are a lot of deleted files (the old font files in `output/chtml/fonts`, `output/common/fonts` and `output/svg/fonts`, as well as deleted `preload.js` files in the `components/src` directories.  

Also, there are new component files for the `-nofont` versions of the combined components like `tex-chtml` (so there is now `tex-chtml-nofont` in addition).  Also, all the original combined configuration files have been modified to allow them to load a user-specified font, and that touches a lot of files, but all in the same way, so you should not have to look at all of them.  I've added a `components/src/output/util.js` file so that the chtml and svg output components can share common code, and that is really the heart of the changes, here.  This is what allows the components to load user-specified fonts.  I'll say more about the details of that in a minute.  The utility file exports an object with `config()` and `loadFont()` methods, and the chtml and svg output components use these to set up the configurations they need, and export their own version of `loadFont()` that can be used by combined components to check for whether a font needs to be loaded or not.  You may just want to view the `components/src/output/chtml.js` and `components/src/output/svg.js` files separately rather than try to figure the deletions and insertions, as most of what they used to do has been moved to the `util.js` file, and it is confusing to look at the diffs.  Also, the chtml and svg `nofont.js` files have been overhauled to provide a generic (empty) font object.

The startup component's `init.js` has been modified to include an exported function that does the work that `components/src/startup/startup.js` used to do, so that the combined components can pass that to the `loadFont()` functions (see below for details).  This also allows the `loader.preLoad()` calls to be moved out of a separate `import from 'preload.js'` to the body of the main component file (which is why the `preload.js` files have been deleted).

The `webpack.common.js` file has an added function that adds the remapping of the default font to the `nofont.js` file, since this is needed for all the `*-nofont` combined configurations.  This simplifies the component definition files for the no-font components.

The chtml and svg output jax are modified to get their default font from a `DefaultFont.js` file rather than the old `TeXFont` that has been removed.  The `DefaultFont.js` file loads and exports the `node_module` file for the font as well as the font name.  I could not get this to work using a `.ts` file, as the font module references `mathjax-full`, and even with the link for `mathjax-full` above, typescript seemed to be confused about finding the `.d.ts` files for the `mathjax-full` references (if they were in place from a previous compile, it was OK, but on a fresh one, they either couldn't be found, or typescript wanted to overwrite them).  The `DefaultFont.js` approach was the only thing I could get to work, and I ran out of time trying to work around it, so this is something we can look into fixing after the alpha release.  I added `DefaultFont.d.ts` to give typescript the types, which seemed to avoid the problems.  I took this file from the one created by compiling the font module, but changed the `mathjax-full` references to be relative paths instead (and cleaned up the file a bit).  Again, this can be straightened out later.

The `package.json` file has the new dependency, and also a modified compile script so that some new `DefaultFont.js` files are moved to the `js` directory when the `ts` files are compiled so they can be found by webpack when it builds the components.

The contextual menu is modified to use `handleRetriesFor()` when changing the output renderer, since it may need to wait for a font to load before trying to re-render the page with the new output jax.

A new `output` configuration block is used to provide common configuration options for both svg and chtml output jax, so that you don't have to duplicate them in both configuration blocks.  So, for example,

``` js
MathJax = {
  output: {
    font: "mathjax-asana"
  }
}
```

could be used to select the Asana font, and that would apply to both chtml and svg output (even if you changed via the contextual menu).

The main work of checking for and loading the fonts is in the `components/src/output/util.js` file.  The `font` option used to be for a `FontData` class to use, but now it is a string that identifies the font to use (see below), and `fontData` is used for a `FontData` class to use.  (For backward compatibility, if `font` isn't a string, it is moved to `fontData`, and `font` is set to the object's `NAME`.)

The `font` string can be one of three things:  the name of a font, like `mathjax-modern`, a MathJax path identifier, like `[mathjax-asana]`, or an absolute URL to a font component.  For a bracketed path, MathJax assumes you have already set up the `loader.paths` value for the font, and will use that to load the font.  Otherwise, it define a `loader.paths` path for the font.  If it is an explicit URL, that is what will be used for the font; if it is a string, it will use the output jax's `fontPath` configuration to set up the path.  The `fontPath` is a string where `%%FONT%%` will be replaced by the font name to create the URL for the font.  When used in node application, it will be `@mathjax/%%FONT%%-font/es5/output/fonts/%%FONT%%`, and when used with a browser, it is `https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/%%FONT%%-font/es5/output/fonts/%%FONT%%`, so that the font will be taken from `jsdelivr` (regardless of where MathJax itself was loaded).  The the v3 lab, you could add

``` 
  output: {
    fontPath: 'mathjax3/node_modules/%%FONT%%-font/es5/output/fonts/%%FONT%%'
  },
```

to get a local copy of the font.

Once the path has been set up, MathJax will check to see if the font is the default font, and if not, it will set up a callback that has MathJax load the desired font using that path (e.g., as `[mathjax-asana]/chtml`).  That font will set up the output jax configuration as needed (the `fontData` class, the prefix used for loading dynamic portions of the font, and for CHTML fonts, the `fontURL` for the woff files).  If the font is the default font, since the component file for the font isn't being loaded, that configuration needs to be done by hand.

All of this is handled in the `config()` operation of the `util.js` file, which is called by the `components/src/output/chtml/chtml.js` or `svg/svg.js` files.

The `loadFont()` method of the `util.js` file is given the `startup()` function from `startup/init.js` along with the jax and font names, and marks the font as being preloaded (if requested).  Then it checks if the font needs to be loaded (via the loaders `checkReady()` function for the jax that was set up in `config()` earlier), and loads the font if so, performing the `startup()` action when the font is loaded.  If there is no font to load (the default is being used), then run the startup action immediately.  Any errors are trapped and reported.

comment.body: I should have mentioned that I only have `mathjax-modern` and `mathjax-tex` as npm packages at the moment, but will make packages for the other fonts soon.  But you can use `mathjax-tex` as a test of setting the `font` configuration option, and it shoddy give you the old MathJax TeX font (you can see the difference readily in the double-struck characters, for example).

could be used to select the Asana font, and that would apply to both chtml and svg output (even if you changed via the contextual menu).

The main work of checking for and loading the fonts is in the `components/src/output/util.js` file.  The `font` option used to be for a `FontData` class to use, but now it is a string that identifies the font to use (see below), and `fontData` is used for a `FontData` class to use.  (For backward compatibility, if `font` isn't a string, it is moved to `fontData`, and `font` is set to the object's `NAME`.)

The `font` string can be one of three things:  the name of a font, like `mathjax-modern`, a MathJax path identifier, like `[mathjax-asana]`, or an absolute URL to a font component.  For a bracketed path, MathJax assumes you have already set up the `loader.paths` value for the font, and will use that to load the font.  Otherwise, it define a `loader.paths` path for the font.  If it is an explicit URL, that is what will be used for the font; if it is a string, it will use the output jax's `fontPath` configuration to set up the path.  The `fontPath` is a string where `%%FONT%%` will be replaced by the font name to create the URL for the font.  When used in node application, it will be `@mathjax/%%FONT%%-font/es5/output/fonts/%%FONT%%`, and when used with a browser, it is `https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/%%FONT%%-font/es5/output/fonts/%%FONT%%`, so that the font will be taken from `jsdelivr` (regardless of where MathJax itself was loaded).  The the v3 lab, you could add

``` 
  output: {
    fontPath: 'mathjax3/node_modules/%%FONT%%-font/es5/output/fonts/%%FONT%%'
  },
```

to get a local copy of the font.

Once the path has been set up, MathJax will check to see if the font is the default font, and if not, it will set up a callback that has MathJax load the desired font using that path (e.g., as `[mathjax-asana]/chtml`).  That font will set up the output jax configuration as needed (the `fontData` class, the prefix used for loading dynamic portions of the font, and for CHTML fonts, the `fontURL` for the woff files).  If the font is the default font, since the component file for the font isn't being loaded, that configuration needs to be done by hand.

All of this is handled in the `config()` operation of the `util.js` file, which is called by the `components/src/output/chtml/chtml.js` or `svg/svg.js` files.

The `loadFont()` method of the `util.js` file is given the `startup()` function from `startup/init.js` along with the jax and font names, and marks the font as being preloaded (if requested).  Then it checks if the font needs to be loaded (via the loaders `checkReady()` function for the jax that was set up in `config()` earlier), and loads the font if so, performing the `startup()` action when the font is loaded.  If there is no font to load (the default is being used), then run the startup action immediately.  Any errors are trapped and reported.

pull_request.title: New font location
pull_request.body:
This PR changes the directory structure for the font data from `ts/output/<jax>/fonts/<name>` to `ts/output/fonts/<name>/<jax>` so that additional fonts are easier to handle (all their font data is in one directory rather than split into separate output jax directories).  This also makes it possible to use a single configuration path to locate an extra font, so that third-party fonts are easier to handle, and so that if the user switches the output jax, the same font path can be used (with the new jax appended).  We also add a new `output` option where the common options for both output jax can be placed, so that configuration will be the same for both.

Most of the changes in this PR are for renaming the various font files, so it looks like a lot, but mostly is just file name changes.

commits.message: Adjust how \end{...} is handled for user-defined environments to avoid a potential recusion loop

Merge pull request #856 from mathjax/fix-newenvironment

Adjust how \end{...} is handled for user-defined environments to avoid a potential recusion loop

pull_request.title: Adjust how \end{...} is handled for user-defined environments to avoid a potential recusion loop
pull_request.body:
This PR changes how the `\end` is handled for a user-defined environment so that `parser.Parse()` isn't called, avoiding a potential infinite loop.

In this PR, the end material from the `\newenvironment` is inserted into the parser string (with `addArgs()` so buffer overflow is checked) along with a following `\end{...}`, but we record the fact that we have already added the end material by setting a stack environment value so that the second `\end{}` will actually finish the environment.  This avoids the recursive loop triggered by something like

``` latex
\newenvironment{a}{x}{y\end{a}}
\begin{a} ... \end{a}
```

and it now generates the proper error about `\end{a}` without a `\begin{a}`.

commits.message: Handle missing and invalid brackets in alignedat like LaTeX does.
Fix handling of bracket arguments in multilined environment to be consistent with LaTeX

Merge pull request #844 from mathjax/fix-align-2

Handle missing and invalid brackets in alignedat like LaTeX does.

pull_request.title: Handle missing and invalid brackets in alignedat like LaTeX does.
pull_request.body:
This PR fixes a problem reported by Peter where `alignedat` would typeset its number argument when there is no bracket argument.  It also handles invalid bracket arguments like LaTeX does (the number argument is parsed after the brackets, then the brackets are typeset).  These issues were introduced by #842, which would reset the `parser.i` value to before the brackets when they were empty to invalid.  Now we re-insert the bracket argument if it is non-empty and invalid (like LaTeX does).

After #842,

``` latex
\begin{alignedat}{2} a \end{alignedat}
```

would typeset as `2a` when it should just be `a`.  This PR should resolve that.

Also,

``` latex
\begin{alignedat}[x]{2} a \end{alignedat}
```

would produce `[x]2a`, but now should produce `[x]a` as LaTeX does.

issue.title: Support repeat/logic control for `newcommand` extension
issue.body:
I want to simulate some commands which supported by amsmath package, but without logic control, it won't be possible, so I wonder is there any way to do this, or will you add this feature?

Syntax might like this:
```
\newcommand\hdotsfor[1]{%
  \foreach \index in {1, ..., #1} {%
   \ifnum\index!=1{$}  \cdots %
  }}
```

Invoke `\hdotsfor{3}` will get:
$$
\cdots & \cdots & \cdots
$$

comment.body:
This is outside the scope of MathJax's mission.  MathJax doesn't implement the low-level looping and flow-control macros.  This is partly to avoid code bloat for control sequences that are going to be rarely used, but also because MathJax is written in javascript, and you can implement your own control sequences with javascript definitions.  How that is done depends on which version of MathJax you are using, but there are certainly examples in the issues here and in the [MathJax user's forum](https://groups.google.com/g/mathjax-users).

If you are really keen on having such macros, you could write a TeX input jax extension that implements them.  That would be a nice project, and a useful contribution to MathJax.

Also, I think `\foreach` is a TikZ command, not a regular LaTeX command, but I'm not certain about that.  And is the dollar sign in your example supposed to be an ampersand?

issue.title: MathjaxV2: Can't render elements and get result synchronously
issue.body:
### Issue Summary
With `MathJax.Hub.Queue`, Seems that after 'Typeset' job done, the elements still will not be rendered fully, but outer code block can get the result I want to get, but outer code block will not always act like this, consider it will be executed asynchronously.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16933298/190859002-6ab3e297-57d5-4dcd-9ecd-2b26a9ed4fee.png)

### Steps to Reproduce:
After script loaded, just execute the following code in browser console:
```
var mathbox = document.createElement('div'); 
mathbox.innerHTML='$$\sum_x^33$$'
MathJax.Hub.Queue(
  ['Typeset', MathJax.Hub, mathbox, () => {console.log('callback', mathbox.innerHTML);}],
  ["PreProcess",MathJax.Hub],
  ["Delay",MathJax.Callback,5000],
  ["Process",MathJax.Hub],

  [() => {console.log('queue-next', mathbox.innerHTML);}]
);
console.log('outer', mathbox.innerHTML)
```

Any other information you want to share that is relevant to the issue
being reported. Especially, why do you consider this to be a bug? What
do you expect to happen instead?
I want to have “callback”, “queue-next”, 'outer' all get the same result, rather than get an incomplete rendered DOM object with “processing” styles.
The documentation mentioned that typeset will call the callback function after its process completed, and for all jobs pushed into the Queue, should be executed synchronously, but I can't get the rendered result like outside code block can.


### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 2.7.9
* Client OS: Windows
* Browser: Firefox 102

I am using the following MathJax configuration:
MathJax default

and loading MathJax via

``` html
    <script src="https://unpkg.com/mathjax@2.7.9/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS_CHTML"></script>

```

comment.body:
MathJax v2 relies on the element containing the mathematics to be part of a live DOM, meaning it must be part of a page being displayed in the browser.  Your example creates a `div` node that is not part of any DOM, and so MathJax can't process it properly, and as a result, you are not getting the fully typeset result.  If you do

``` js
var mathbox = document.createElement('div'); 
document.body.append(mathbox);
mathbox.innerHTML='$$\\sum_x^33$$'
MathJax.Hub.Queue(
  ['Typeset', MathJax.Hub, mathbox, () => {console.log('callback', mathbox.innerHTML);}],
  ["PreProcess",MathJax.Hub],
  ["Delay",MathJax.Callback,5000],
  ["Process",MathJax.Hub],

  [() => {console.log('queue-next', mathbox.innerHTML);}]
);
console.log('outer', mathbox.innerHTML)
```

you should get the proper result for both the `callback` and `queue-next` output.  Note, however, that the `outer` output may or may not produce the correct result, as the commands that follow the `MathJax.Hub.Queue` call may run *before* the code in the queue itself, and that depends on both what may already be in the queue, as well as what browser you are using and on what OS. 

For example, the `outer` result for me is the original un-typeset TeX, because in my web page, the initial typeset run hasn't been performed yet when I make the `MathJax.Hub.Queue()` call, and so the commands following the `MathJax.Hub.Queue()` command are performed before the ones that you are pushing onto the queue.  Note that the `output` result is shown *before* the output for the other callbacks, indicating that the `console.log()` function is running *before* the items that have been added to the queue.  The `Typeset` command includes some delays (as so the `PreProcess` and `Process` commands, as well as your own `Delay` command) and so the code following the `MathJax.Hub.Queue()` will definitely run before MathJax can completed the `Typeset` command.

In any case, adding the `div` to the page will allow MathJax to complete the processing properly, and your `queue-next` result should be correct, and you can not rely on the `outer` output, as it will run before the queued commands are completed.

Note that I also doubled the backslash in the TeX code when you set the `innerHTML` so that an actual backslash will be part of the string, as backslashes are escape characters in Javascript string literals.

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

comment.body: I've made a PR that resolves the issue (by refactoring the `SerializedMmlVisitor` code so that can be used by `MathMLVisitor` as well).

pull_request.title: Refactor MathML visitors to make MathMLVisitor work like SerializedMml. (mathjax/MathJax#2920)
pull_request.body: This PR makes the MathMLVisitor work more like the SerializedMmlVisitor in terms of handling of attributes and converting TeXAtom nodes to mrows.  Common code has been moved to the common MmlVisitor class that is the root for both.  This invalid moving the static data items from SerializedMmlVisitor to MmlVisitor, as well as the protected methods for managing the attribute lists, so the big chunk of additions to MmlVisitor is just moving the code from SerializedMmlVisitor.  The handling of TeXAtom nodes as a special case has been removed in favor of a translation table for the node kind.  Support for the new HTML nodes has been added to the MathMLVisitor.

pull_request.title: Initialize the output jax when switching renderers for the first time. (mathjax/MathJax#2924)
pull_request.body:
This PR makes sure the SVG global font cache is set up when you switch renderers using the contextual menu.  It does so by calling the `initialize()` method for the output jax when it is first loaded.

To test, use the lab and set the font cache to global in the SVG output options, then go back to CHTML and "keep" the page.  Switch to SVG after it is released.  Without the patch, there should be an error message in the console, but with the patch, the change of renderers should occur properly.

Resolves issue mathjax/MathJax#2924.

issue.title: MathJax(tex-mml-chtml.js) throws error in Firefox, no problem in chrome.

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

issue.body: ----- ### Issue Summary MathJax(tex-mml-chtml.js) throws error in Firefox, no problem in chrome. ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. open https://math.yish.org/ (firefox) 2. open developer tools ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: 3.2 * Client OS: (e.g., Mac OS X 10.8.4) * Browser: (e.g., Chrome 29.0.1547.57) Code: https://github.com/mokeyish/Latex-Equation-Editor/blob/master/latex_equation_editor.htm ### Supporting information: * Please supply a link to a (live) minimal example page, when possible. * If your issue is with the display of the mathematics produced by MathJax, include a screen snapshot that illustrates the problem, when possible. * Check your browser console window for any error messages, and include them here. * Include the MathJax configuration you are using, and the script tag that loads MathJax itself.

comment.body:
The issue is not browser-based *per se*, it is that in Firefox you seem to have used the MathJax contextual menu to select the SVG output renderer, which is what is triggering the problem.  It looks like when the SVG output is set to use a global cache, and the default renderer is CHTML but the user has selected the SVG renderer, the global cache isn't set up initially as it should be, and so when MathJax tries to add characters to the cache, it fails with this error.

I will make a PR to resolve the situation, but for now, either use a local cache, or don't switch to SVG output.

issue.title: change thickmathspace in \bmod to 5/18em

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

issue.body:
`$\bmod$` is currently converted to
```xml
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
  <mo lspace="thickmathspace" rspace="thickmathspace">mod</mo>
</math>
```
It seems that `thickmathspace` was [removed](https://github.com/w3c/mathml/issues/75) from MathML core.
It would be good to change `thickmathspace` in `\bmod` to 0.2777em
In Firefox 102, the console will show a warning:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53823634/179365332-a209a834-4ab5-4062-8f00-54d85a3a4789.png)

In Firefox Nightly, the console will show an error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53823634/179364871-fb8fcd60-b2bb-4ccb-a208-cf31af22f812.png)

comment.body: I've made a PR to address the problem in the next release.

pull_request.title: Change usage of thickmathspace to numeric value in \bmod.  (mathjax/MathJax#2902)
pull_request.body: This PR removes the explicit use of `thickmathspace` in `\bmod` and uses the numeric equivalent instead.  It also makes a variable for `em(MATHSPACE.thickmathspace)` and uses that so that it doesn't have to be computed multiple times.
